awd_titl_txt: Responsible Research and Engagement Practices for Indigenous Data Governance in Earth Science Institutions
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to identify ethical practices for large open data research projects. It will contribute to creating networks for Indigenous scholars and community members, data managers and social scientists to develop processes and guidelines for databases that ensure data collection, storage, and dissemination are done in ethical ways for stakeholders. The project will engage scientists and community members working with data stored in the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) database as a pilot effort. The project’s outcomes will be of interest to researchers, community members, policy makers and educators. 

The goal of the project is to develop processes and guidelines that are applicable across Earth science data repositories and address Indigenous Data topics in each stage of the data and specimen lifecycle (i.e. collection, storage, publication, citation, re-use). In this incubation phase, the project will rely on working group interactions and use a participatory research framework to develop guidelines that can be applied broadly across Earth science research and open data repositories. Throughout planning and implementation, the project will connect to the people and institutions in the Rising Voices Network to build a robust collaboration of participants that includes Indigenous scholars, educators, and community leaders as well as atmospheric, social, ecological, and data scientists.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes

The Earth Data Relations (EDR) Working Group  convened under the “Responsible Research and Engagement Practices for Indigenous Data Governance in Earth Science Institutions” project to explore the many facets of the practice of Open Science within the broad field of Earth Systems Science. The group represented diverse perspectives and ways of knowing across disciplines, geographies, and research efforts. Participants included individuals from more than 14 distinct Indigenous Peoples and eight regions within the United States and territories, as well as 6 non-Indigenous allies. Working group members represent diverse career stages, institution types (federal, academic and research institutions, nonprofits), and disciplinary expertise (life science, social science, climate science, policy, data management, data science).

Through facilitated virtual meetings that honored both Indigenous and settler colonial methodologies and knowledge systems, the EDRWG explored the questions:

  1. How do we define Indigenous Data in Earth science open data networks?
  2. How do the CARE Principles for Indigenous Data Governance (Collective benefit, Authority to control, Responsibility, and Ethics) apply to the collection of climate and ecological data? How are we crediting Indigenous knowledge holders in climate and ecological databases?
  3. What does implementation of CARE principles mean for each stage of the data and specimen lifecycle (i.e. planning, collection, storage, publication, citation, re-use)?

The CARE Principles for Indigenous Data Governance provided a framework through which to assess research practices, and the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) provided a use case through which to consider CARE implementation across the data and specimen lifecycle.

As the responsibilities and relationships that Indigenous People hold to the land is not limited to federally recognized Tribal lands, the EDRWG asserts that Indigenous data likewise are not limited geographically but are defined by Indigenous People based on historical and current connections to place. The group considered the shared responsibility of every person and organization in the research pathway and the complexity with which change happens across the spectrum from individual researcher to multi-national governing bodies.  At any level, the working group identified opportunities to engage with Indigenous Peoples to collaboratively define what visibility and acknowledgement look like within existing data landscapes and developed the EDR recommendations (Jennings et al, forthcoming) to help guide Earth science projects, institutions, and repositories through a self-assessment and subsequent implementation to integrate CARE Principles in their research contexts. 

Specifically, the EDR Working Group recommends:

  1. Adopt ongoing internal learning and assessment practices – As part of the design and planning phase of a project, consider institutional or researcher position and intention with respect to engagement with Indigenous Peoples. Commit time and resources in the planning phase before reaching out to communities or initiating research activities.
  2. Develop collaborative access permission and research protocols – In coordination with Indigenous communities connected to place, acknowledge the impact of research activities and, as needed, establish formalized understanding through Memoranda of Understanding (MOU), Memoranda of Agreement (MOA), research permits, or other preferred means to document site access agreements and collection protocols.
  3. Enhance data and specimen management infrastructure – Based on community requests, integrate governance into data and specimen management practices. This may include application of Indigenous metadata or labeling, controlled access to data, or plans for data or specimen return or disposal.
  4. Enhance data relations at all stages of the data lifecycle – Sharing processes and practices with the research community reinforces the partnership with Indigenous Peoples and normalizes ethical practices across disciplines.

These actions are not intended as one-off activities but instead lay the foundation for positive and lasting change across the Earth science research community. The EDR recommendations support transitioning relationships with Indigenous stewards from adversarial or transactional to relational resulting in science that upholds sovereign rights of Indigenous Peoples and respects, and benefits from, multiple ways of knowing.
